label: def-mean-field-phase-space
nl_definition: The single-particle phase space $\Omega$ is the Cartesian product of the domain of valid positions $X_{\text{valid}}$ and the closed ball of allowed velocities $V_{\text{alg}}$.

formal_conditions.text: The single-particle phase space, denoted $\Omega$, is the Cartesian product of the valid position and velocity domains:

properties.name: Complete Kinematic States
properties.description: Defines the complete set of possible kinematic states (position and velocity) a particle can occupy.

properties.name: Dependence on Constraints
properties.description: Its properties are a direct translation of the constraints imposed on the walkers in the discrete Euclidean Gas algorithm.

notes.text: The phase space defines the complete set of possible kinematic states—position and velocity—that a particle can occupy.

label: def-phase-space-density
nl_definition: The phase-space sub-probability density $f(t,x,v)$ describing the state of the swarm's alive population at time $t \ge 0$.

formal_conditions.text: The mass of alive walkers in $A$ is given by the integral:
formal_conditions.latex: \text{Alive mass in } A = \int_A f(t, z) dz.

formal_conditions.text: The total mass of alive walkers $m_a(t)$ is bounded by 1:

properties.name: Domain/Codomain
properties.description: $f: [0, \infty) \times \Omega \to [0, \infty)$

properties.name: Interpretation
properties.description: A high value signifies a high concentration of probability mass.

parameters.description: Any measurable subset of the phase space $\Omega$

notes.text: The total mass of dead walkers is $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$.
The evolution is described by a coupled system for $f(t,z)$ and $m_d(t)$ that conserves the total mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.

label: def-mean-field-moments
nl_definition: Functionals of the phase-space density $f(t, \cdot)$ representing the reward moments ($\mu_R[f], \sigma_R^2[f]$) and distance moments ($\mu_D[f], \sigma_D^2[f]$) computed relative to the normalized density of the alive population $f(t,z) / m_a(t)$.

formal_conditions.text: The mean reward moment $\mu_R[f](t)$ is computed as the expected value over the normalized alive population:
The reward variance moment $\sigma_R^2[f](t)$:
The mean distance moment $\mu_D[f](t)$ is the expectation of the distance between two particles drawn independently from the normalized alive population:
The distance variance moment $\sigma_D^2[f](t)$:

properties.name: Dependence on $f$
properties.description: The moments are functionals of $f$, denoted by the notation $\mu[f]$.

properties.name: Normalization
properties.description: Moments are computed using the normalized density $f(t,z) / m_a(t)$.

parameters.description: Total alive mass, defined as $m_a(t) = \int_{\Omega} f(t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z$.
The reward function dependent on state $z$.
The distance metric between states represented by $\varphi(z)$ and $\varphi(z')$.

notes.text: These moments are defined as the mean-field limit replacements for empirical statistics computed over finite sets of alive walkers.
The notation $\mu[f]$ emphasizes that these are numbers depending on the entire shape of the function $f$.

label: def-mean-field-patched-std
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Regularized Standard Deviations are functionals of the density $f$, derived by applying a regularization function $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}$ to the mean-field variance functionals $\sigma_R^2[f](t)$ and $\sigma_D^2[f](t)$.

formal_conditions.text: Definition of $\widehat{\sigma}_R[f](t)$
Definition of $\widehat{\sigma}_D[f](t)$

parameters.description: The density function, a functional argument.
The mean-field variance functional (likely referring to diffusion term).
The Regularized Standard Deviation function (from abstract framework).

notes.text: These are introduced to ensure numerical stability by preventing denominators from approaching zero, especially when the true variance $\sigma^2[f]$ is close to zero (highly converged swarm).

label: def-mean-field-z-scores
nl_definition: The mean-field Z-scores for a particle at state $z$ and a potential companion at state $z_c$ at time $t$, denoted $\widetilde{r}[f]$ and $\widetilde{d}[f]$, are standardized versions of raw measurements derived using global, density-dependent moments.

formal_conditions.text: The mean-field Z-scores at time $t$ for a particle at state $z$ and a potential companion at state $z_c$ are defined as:

parameters.description: Implied dependency on the density functional or context.
The mean-field Z-score associated with the raw measurement $R(z)$.
The mean-field Z-score associated with the raw measurement $d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z),\varphi(z_c))$.
Global, density-dependent moment (mean) for the $R$ measurement.
Global, density-dependent moment (standard deviation) for the $R$ measurement.
Raw measurement of distance between transformed states.
Global, density-dependent moment (mean) for the $d$ measurement.
Global, density-dependent moment (standard deviation) for the $d$ measurement.

notes.text: These scores are defined using density-dependent functionals derived in Section 1.2.

label: def-mean-field-fitness-potential
nl_definition: The Mean-Field Fitness Potential, denoted $V[f](z, z_c, t)$, is a functional of the density $f$ that combines scaled contributions from the diversity functional $\widetilde{d}$ and the reward functional $\widetilde{r}$ multiplicatively, determining the fitness of a particle at state $z$ relative to a companion at $z_c$.

formal_conditions.text: The Mean-Field Fitness Potential $V[f](z,z_c,t)$ is constructed by applying the canonical `Rescale Transformation` $g_A$ to the mean-field Z-scores:

properties.name: Functional Dependence
properties.description: It is a functional of the density $f$, denoted $V[f]$.

properties.name: Multiplicative Combination
properties.description: Combines contributions from the reward and diversity channels multiplicatively.

properties.name: Balance Role
properties.description: Allows the algorithm to balance the drive for high rewards (exploitation) with the need to maintain diversity (exploration).

notes.text: The use of $V[f]$ emphasizes that the potential is a functional of the density $f$, meaning its value depends on the global shape of the entire probability distribution.

label: def-baoab-update-rule
nl_definition: The five sequential steps used by the Bond-Angle-Oriented-Angle-Bond (BAOAB) method to advance the state $(x_n, v_n)$ of a single particle from time $t_n$ to $t_{n+1} = t_n + \tau$.

formal_conditions.text: B-Step (Force Kick): Velocity update using a half-step kick from the conservative force $F(x)$.
A-Step (Position Drift): Position update with a half-step drift using the new velocity.
O-Step (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck): Velocity update for a full timestep by exactly solving the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process.
A-Step (Position Drift): Position update with a final half-step drift.
B-Step (Force Kick): Final velocity update with a half-step kick using the force evaluated at the new position $F(x_{n+1})$.

properties.name: Symmetry
properties.description: The method composes analytically solvable parts symmetrically.

properties.name: Type
properties.description: Splits the SDE (implied to be associated with the Euclidean Gas specification) into solvable parts.

parameters.description: State of the particle (position and velocity) at time $t_n$.
Conservative force derived from the potential.
Flow field evaluated at the midpoint position $x_{n+1/2}$.
Friction coefficient in the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process.

notes.text: All parameters are assumed to be as defined in the Euclidean Gas specification.
Intermediate velocity states $v_{n+1/2}^{(1)}$ and $v_{n+1/2}^{(2)}$, and intermediate position $x_{n+1/2}$ are calculated.

label: def-kinetic-generator
nl_definition: The kinetic evolution of a single alive walker $i$ is governed by an underdamped Langevin SDE, and the infinitesimal generator for the N-particle system under these independent SDEs is the Fokker-Planck operator $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$, acting on a test function $f$ on the swarm state space of alive walkers $\mathcal{A}$.

properties.name: Continuous Stochastic Process
properties.description: Governs the evolution between cloning events/death/revival transitions.

properties.name: Discrete Approximation
properties.description: The kinetic stage (BAOAB integrator) is a discrete-time approximation of this SDE.

parameters.description: Index for a single alive walker.
Force acting on walker $i$ at position $x_i$.

label: def-killing-operator
nl_definition: The concept is twofold: first, an interior killing rate $c$ defined by specific properties relating to its smoothness and location relative to a safe subset and boundary layer; second, the total mass killed per unit time, which is a functional defined by integrating the product of the killing rate and the alive density $f$ over the domain $\Omega$.

properties.name: Non-negativity of rate $c$
properties.description: The interior killing rate $c$ is a non-negative function, $c: \Omega \to [0, \infty)$.

parameters.description: Spatial domain over which integration occurs.
Alive density at time $t$ and position $z$.

notes.text: The killing operator acts by removing mass from the alive density $f$ at a rate proportional to the density itself, $c(z)f(z)$.

label: def-revival-operator
nl_definition: The Revival Operator $B[f, m_d](t, z)$ models the re-injection of mass from the dead population back into the alive population, proportional to the current alive density.

formal_conditions.text: The Revival Operator is defined as:
The total mass revived per unit time is:

properties.name: Interpretation
properties.description: Models revival as a source term re-injecting mass from the dead population back into the alive population.

properties.name: Spatial Profile
properties.description: The spatial profile of the re-injected mass is proportional to the current alive density, $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$.

parameters.description: The Revival Operator, dependent on the alive density function $f$, the dead mass $m_d$, time $t$, and spatial position $z$.
The normalized alive density (the probability distribution over the alive population).

notes.text: Dead walkers are instantly revived by cloning from alive companions, leading to the revival mass being proportional to the current alive density.

label: def-cloning-generator
nl_definition: The Internal Cloning Operator, $S[f]$, which represents the mean-field limit of the discrete cloning mechanism, is defined as the difference between source ($S_{\text{src}}[f]$) and sink ($S_{\text{sink}}[f]$) terms.

formal_conditions.text: The Internal Cloning Operator $S[f](t, z)$ is decomposed into sink and source terms:
formal_conditions.latex: S[f](t, z) = S_{\text{src}}[f](t, z) - S_{\text{sink}}[f](t, z)

formal_conditions.text: Sink term:
Source term:
formal_conditions.latex: S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau m_a(t)} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(t,z_d) f(t,z_c) P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c) Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c

properties.name: Mean-field limit
properties.description: It is the mean-field limit of the discrete cloning mechanism.

properties.name: Mass-neutral
properties.description: The operator is mass-neutral by construction, meaning $\int_{\Omega} S[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z = 0$.

properties.name: Non-local
properties.description: The operator is non-local.

parameters.description: The Internal Cloning Operator evaluated at time $t$ and state $z$.
The total mass at time $t$ (implied by context, related to $\int f(t,z) dz$).
The cloning probability depending on fitness values computed from the normalized alive density $f/m_a$.
The jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity).

notes.text: $1/\tau$ converts per-step probabilities to continuous rates.

label: def-transport-operator
nl_definition: The Transport Operator, denoted $L^\dagger$, is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of the backward kinetic generator $L$, acting on a density $f$ and represented as the negative divergence of the probability flux vector $J$.

properties.name: Adjoint Relationship
properties.description: It is the formal $L^2$-adjoint of the backward kinetic generator $L$.

properties.name: Conservative Form
properties.description: It is written in conservative form as the negative divergence of the probability flux vector $J$.
